ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about different energy sources and their advantages and disadvantages, as well as energy production, storage, and distribution, as well as climate change
Quantitative and analytical skills that can investigate renewable energy technologies, their feasibility, and the fundamental principles behind them.
general facts and knowledge about different energy production technolgoies.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Covered a lot of material with good analysis which was good.

Bad part was it felt very rushed and unorganized and weekly quizzes were unhelpful for learning and very challenging

W: Unorganized (slides and ideas within each topic), Unnecessarily challenging, fairly inaccessible to general energy studies students (ample amount of quantitative work on psets such that it is hard for a MechE student and brutal for a non-MechE). 
S: Fascinating, wide variety of applicable technologies within renewable energy, healthy skepticism on all technologies talked about, very practical view of the energy transition and what it will take, extremely useful for further work in the energy industry

Weekly quizzes are ridiculous. The average is like 50/60 and super niche answers. Homweorks are awful. Super technical from like real physics textbooks and requires skills that are not taught at all in class. Disconnect with difficulty of homeworks and the rest of the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are at all interested in climate change, absolutely. This is the best environmental studies elective I took, and I took very many to complete the energy studies certificate. It teaches basic physics which is rare for a survey course so I was applying lots of my engineering knowledge in interesting ways

Know what you are getting into; weekly mechanical engineering psets (where the physics and science on the pset are not taught in class but must be read from an energy physics textbook), bi-weekly quizzes (on the slides of the past two weeks and semi-random specific things within them), and a Tues-Thurs 9:00 am. If you love renewable energy, want to work in the industry, are comfortable with really quantitative stuff, and ok with a course that will be frustrating and hard at points but that is on an essential topic, go for it.

Not at all. Gomez is a super intresting and knowledgable guy, but class isint set up well, he's to hard on something that should be a senior level class taken out of intrest in the topic. He just makes HWs way too hard which doesnt help anything.
